(Buffalo Bill) Cody is describing the finale of his great Wild West Show: Cody I see General George Armstrong Custer leading the courageous men of the Seventh Cavalry deep deep deeper into the Injun territory known as Little Big Horn on a Mission of Peace. Prentiss Excuse me. Bill. You know it wasn't really Little Big Horn. It was the Greasy Grass River. Cody Prentiss, I already got the programs printed. . . . The general halts his troops and they set up camp, exhausted from their historic and humane journey carrying the wounds of a cowardly Sioux ambush from the day before. Prentiss Bill, it was a Sioux defense against a cavalry ambush. Cody As the day ends, the valley is quiet as a tomb. Then, suddenly, Injuns appear. More Injuns than anybody's ever seen. Publicist Mate Salsbury begins shouting through his megaphone, cueing the action, prompting the actors. . . . The Indians enter, led by Chief Sitting Bull in full Sioux warbonnet and buckskins. Cody Custer knows it’s gonna be a fight for his life, so he writes a quick farewell note to his beautiful wife while the cannon's being loaded. 1 Prentiss Bill, Custer didn’t have a cannon at Greasy Grass River. Cody Prentiss, there's reason to believe he had one on order. So we've just delivered it early. Prentiss I'm just pointin' out the truth of history lessons. Bill. Cody It's about time history took a lesson from us'. — Scene from "Buffalo Bill and the Indians: or Sitting Bull's History Lesson."^ Introduction: The "Unwritten History" In 1913, the real Buffalo Bill Cody was aging and in 'debt. The once great Wild West and Indian Show was near bankruptcy--the days of national tours, presidential perform ances, and appearances before the crowned heads of Europe long completed. Cody was desperate to resurrect past glories and to renew personal fortunes. He approached his debtors with an ambitious plan : If live pageantry, western melodrama, and rodeo shows were too expensive and too sim­ plistic for twentieth-century tastes, then why not resort to the most modern of divertissements— moving pictures? Cody would recreate for film the greatest battles in western history. No expense would be spared, no stone unturned in searching for authenticity and reality. Essenay Studios agreed to handle the films, the United States Secretary of War assigned an entire regiment of soldiers in authentic uniforms, the Secretary of the Interior granted permission for filming on the actual sites at which the battles took place, and the Sioux tribe agreed to reenact its own defeats* William F* Cody Historical Pictures was on its way. Cody decided to begin with the Battle at Wounded Knee, the last major confrontation of the Indian campaigns. Less than twenty-three years had passed since that 1890 battle. Many participants, victors and vanquished alike, still jlived, including the Commander-in-Charge, General Nelson W. Miles. Trying to please the War Department, and hoping to live up to the title of his company, Cody invited Miles to participate in the first film as historical and technical 'advisor. Therein lay the ruin of Buffalo Bill. General Miles turned out to be an exacting and particu­ lar historical advisor. Telegrams and correspondence found among the papers of General Frank D. Baldwin^ indicate that Miles was not pleased with Cody's sense of history. As shooting began. Miles demanded that the photography be taken on the "Kinemacolor principle" as was being used all over the world, and was "a great improvement on the simple colors of black and white. In fact, it is absolutely essential that that system should be used in order to make it historically correct; the Indians are neither white nor black, but are the so noted copper-colored race that is disappearing forever."^ Miles also noted that the War and Interior Departments had 'authorized assistance "provided that it is strictly histor­ ically correct"^ and suggested a series of twelve scenes or tableaus which would accomplish that purpose. Neither Kine­ macolor nor the proposed tableaus were used in the film. Filming began in October, but Miles continued to be displeased. When he saw the completed film in January, 1914, he complained by letter to George E. Spoor, President of the Film Manufacturing Co. of Chicago: We were asked to hurry out to the Plains to assist in reproduc­ tion of the closing scenes of the Indian War. Notwithstanding the fact that the campaign occurred in mid-Winter, we were asked to go out early in October. Arriving at Pine Ridge we were obliged to wait nearly a week while the troops and Indians were engaged in what is officially and publically known as a massacre or the representation of the same . . . Now in behalf of the gallant officers and soldiers who had borne the brunt of the Indian campaigns on our frontier and many of those whose lives have been sacrificed, I am obliged to enter a solemn protest against the misrepresentation and misleading statements made in regard to those pictures.^ Miles' complaints included the fact that a peace conference which was shown as occurring before the final battle, did not occur until afterwards. He complained that the title cards were misleading, because they referred to a "War of the Messiah," which never occurred. A peace council promise that Indians would not be punished if they surren­ dered was never made. Last, Miles complained about the pnusually heroic presence of Buffalo Bill in the film: [T]he announcement is made in bold letters, "The Close of the Indian Wars in America" and the name of Buffalo Bill appears above and below the picture. Under this fraudulent title a march of General Merritt in 1876 and a campaign of General Carr in 1869 is presented, and in those scenes the commands are marched, halted, and manouevered at the dictation of Colonel Cody. Those generals are both dead. They cannot protest against this presentation, but their distinguished record is well-known and it is only necessary to state to any military man the fact they were officers on the frontier when William Cody was a child. Titles were shuffled and some shots were restaged. But the battle was met. Miles wanted autheticity. Cody wanted pizzazz. No one was happy with the result. The finished product reflected Miles' heavy-handed touch. It was relatively authentic— and quite dull. Lacking a focal point, dramatic pace, and human interest, it seemed as aimed at the National Archives, not at an audience.^ Attacked by Nelson Miles and the War Department on one side, and facing poor reviews and poor returns on the other, Buffalo Bill was defeated. The William F. Cody Historical Pictures Co. disappeared before producing another epic. Whether in fictional film or in historical accounts, the interaction between reality and fantasy is complex and continuous. Just as the fictional Buffalo Bill attempted to manipulate reality to fit the shape of his extravagant entertainments, so was the real Buffalo Bill, himself the creator and the product of show business enterprises. In terms of commercial appeal, moving pictures supplanted wild west shows, dime novels, and western pulps as the predomi­ nant form of popular entertainment. Yet, the story of William Cody's Historical Pictures Company illustrates that the twentieth-century's newest gadget was no more prone toward authenticity than other forms of entertainment. In fact, the first few years of film history indicate a contin­ uing struggle over historic and ethnic images in American films. As early as 1911, for example, outraged Indian delega­ tions were arriving in Washington, D.C., to protest the film treatment of Native Americans. On March 18, 1911, Moving Picture World headlined a story, "Indians War on Films," and noted that In order to get thrilling pictures of wild western life, [moving pictures promoters] have used white men costumed as Indians, in depicting scenes that are not true pictures of the Indians, and are in fact, grossly libelous. The Indians are contemplating a call at the White House tomorrow to lay the case before President Taft, and may ask for Congressional action looking to the regulation of moving pictures in which Indians are shown.® There is no indication that President Taft ever received the Indians' case. Nor does history indicate Congressional regulation of the movies in behalf of the Indians. Still, the struggle for accuracy continued. While one contemporary critic bemoaned the existence of "The Make-Believe Indian"® and wondered why thoroughly representative films couldn't be produced while real Indians still existed, W. Stephen Bush wondered why by 1911 filmmak­ ers continued to use the same tired-out ‘ western stereotypes. He attacked what he called "Moving Picture Absurdities": The greatest of them all is the Indian. We have him in every variety but one. We have Indians a la Français, "red" men recruited from the Bowery and upper West End Avenue. We have Licensed Indians and Independent Indians— the only kind we lack are the real Indians. . . . General Sherman said that there were no good Indians except the dead ones. He had never seen the mov­ ing picture Indian. There is no medium of morality about him. He is either wholly good, seemingly transplated from the skies, or else a fiend and an expert scalper in common practice . . . These and similar moulds are worn and cracked and should be thrown away. The surest path to success is the one where "no track of steps has worn a way." Originality is the life of the moving pictures.^ ® Almost from the instant that film was introduced as a popu­ lar entertainment, people were thinking about the impact of film as a purveyor of images and as an unusually persuasive medium of mass communications. One critic talked about film as "the living picture," and predicted that "unwritten 'history" would be the greatest marvel of the future. Sublime, indeed, is the contemplation of the history to be recorded without words, and yet, in a language that speaks to eyes, ears, head, and heart; the living picture is the crown of the ages, the greatest recorder of the past, and the greatest teacher of the future. It is said that in degradation there is a bottomless pit. Surely, then, in culture, there are topless heights, in the climbing of which the picture is of invaluable aid. If it is possible that the future holds a period in which the usefulness of tha.t:picture will be transcended, it would seem that such a state is beyond present comprehension. But even then, in that marvelous age, they will still be reading, like ourselves, that which has never been written, the cinematograph having been the medium of their education.^ ^ 'Fictional filmmaking, at least, has rarely lived up to this glorious prediction. Being a joint venture of expediency and entertainment, movies change personalities, rewrite history, and uproot geography. In Hollywood, budgets are {based upon prospective returns rather than the cost of film accuracy, and casting is done with an eye toward audience appeal rather than authenticity. To that optimistic 1911 writer, today's "living picture" would probably be a crush­ ing disappointment. One argument motivating this study, however, is that film has in fact served effectively as an instrument of "unwritten history." While the validity of specific histor­ ical images will be questioned, it is believed that film does in fact record the past and teach audiences about a vast and complex arrangement of past and present worlds. Anyone who was a boy in the early fifties will remember that when it came time to separate the cowboys from the Indians for after-school play, a small lump of defeat lodged in the throats of the unfortunate child-Indians. Before we could even besiege the settler's fort, we knew that the attack must fail. Indians, of course, never won. And fair-haired heroes never lost. The lesson may not have been accurate, but it was larger than life and more vivid than a book. Our movie textbooks were realer than real. Film Image or Content Studies In recent years students of the film have begun to examine the ways in which movies promote social conceptions, character-typing, and societal values. Two of the earliest examinations into the influences of movies on attitudes and behavior were written by an anthropologist and a political scientist. Hortense Powdermaker wondered what an anthropologist would find when he turned his lens on the movies. She sug­ gested that the researcher could Use the same general premises and point of view in the study of motion pictures as an institution of contemporary society. We define an institution as an organized system of human activities which meet a basic human need. Our frame of refer­ ence is both functional and historical. . . . In other words, we arrive at an understanding.of an institution not by studying it as if it were a separate phenomenon, but in terms of its interrelationships with society as a whole.^ ^ Ms. Powdermaker suggested that a very detailed evaluation of film should reflect social values and goals and should provide valuable information about the society in which the films are produced. Therefore, an analysis of the specific content of American movies should contribute to a deeper understanding of American society. Franklin Fearing, writing in a 1947 issue of the Annals pf the American Academy of Political and Social Sciences, also identified the influence of movies on values and ideas. "With a few special exceptions," he wrote, "everybody— social scientist, movie makers, and laymen--seems to agree that there are profoundly important relationships between motion pictures and human behavior."^ ® Fearing also argued jfor a precise and detailed investigation into the content of motion pictures as one way in which questions about human behavior, communication, and role-identification might be ^studied. According to Fearing, Like the folk tale, classic drama, primitive storytelling, or the medieval morality play, the film may be regarded as a means through which the individual understands himself, his social role, and the values of his group. It is also a means by which the individual orients himself in a universe of events which appear to occur haphazardly and chaotically. . . . The motion picture is not a fixed pattern of meanings or ideas which are received by a passive mind. Rather, what the individual "gets" is determined by his background and his needs. He takes from the picture what is usable for him or what will function in his life.^** >In order to further understand the ways in which motion pic­ tures express and communicate cultural values, social concepts, and desired images, we must examine film in new ways. Fearing says 9 it is necessary to know something about the content of the film, the psychological needs of the persons who are exposed to it, the immediate setting, and the social and cultural forces operating on the persons who make films and the audiences for whom they are intended.^ ® According to Powdermaker, the anthropologist "looks at his movies both functionally and historically. He must analyze the movies themselves, study the audience, and learn about the conditions under which the pictures are made."^ ^ Fearing and Powdermaker both suggest that the first step toward a clear understanding of the interrelationships Detween film and society would be a particularly careful analysis of film images. By looking at film in terms of plot, character, setting, physical appearance, costume, and sets, it would be possible to identify key images and sig­ nificant sequences. By comparing those sequences with corresponding sequences from authentic sources, it would be possible to isolate differences, to notice changes over time, and to understand the ways in which film images are selected and ordered. Having carefully isolated and deline­ ated the most significant images, it would then be possible to analyse the differences and to propose reasons for the changes. It is the general argument of this study that film and society interact in a dynamic way. Film styles and images adapt and alter over time because of social and political [changes in the external world. But images also bring about changes in that outer world, because values, attitudes, and 10 beliefs can be affected when audiences can be analysed. The Lpecific task of this study, therefore, is the careful, jcomparative delineation of film and historical images of the Sioux. Extensive content analysis and detailed film image studies have only recently been appearing. One of the most Lmpressive studies of this type is Siegfried Kracauer's psy­ chological history of the German film. From Caligari to Hitler.In this work, Kracauer charted the relationship I between political and social forces in pre-Hitler Germany to the content and style of German films. He contended that through an analysis of the German films deep psychological dispo­ sitions predominant in Germany from 1918 to 1933 can be exposed [and that] the use made here of films as a medium of research can profitably be extended to studies of current mass behavior in the United States and elsewhere. The analysis of film with specific reference to the political, social, racial, or psychological source and accuracy of given images is an important development, one that merits extension into the areas of American racial stereotyping and historical image development. Marjorie Rosen has attempted to explore the film images of women in her study. Popcorn Venus: Women, Movies, and the American Dream. In her prefatory comments, she makes a clear case |for the values of film image studies : Does art reflect life? In movies, yes. Because more than any other art form, films have been a mirror held up to society's porous face. They therefore reflect the changing societal image of women— which, until recently, has not been taken seriously enough. 11 Does life reflect art? Again, yes. Because of the magnetism of movies— because their glamor and intensity and "entertainment" are so distracting and seemingly innocuous— [audiences] accept their morality or values. Sometimes too often. Too blindly. And tragically.^ ® The purposes of film image studies are to isolate, analyse, and identify the origins of events, personalities, Lnd images which appear on film screens. As a discipline in Æilm history and criticism, image studies are relatively new. Though the Kracauer book first appeared in 194 7, most jof the film image studies which have been published since then, have appeared in the last decade. Image studies about Blacks, Women, Homosexuals, Asians, Indians, and Jews repre­ sent part of the contemporary movement in this direction.^ ° Image studies can serve several valuable functions. In the first place, a comparison of the filmed event with listorical and anthropological sources will help the film ^scholar to understand more clearly the processes of inter­ pretation, distortion, and mythification as they relate to film. In the second place, a comparison of the fictional •film image with the actual historical image will help the social historian to understand the role of film as an agency in image creation and the generation of popular beliefs. In bhe third place, an understanding of the specific forces Dringing about and subsequently changing particular film images will help the film scholar to understand the interre­ lations between film and society. In particular, such an understanding will provide insights' into the societal aspects of genre-based film studies. 12 Image studies, then, relate strongly to the question of film as social history. In his essay, "Ceremonies of Inno­ cence," Michael Wood wrote Throughout this book I have argued and assumed that virtually any Hollywood movie, however trivial, and whatever its intentions, can be seen as a text for a rather special kind of social history: the study of what might be called the back of the American mind, or perhaps the back of certain states of that mind . . . Hollywood sets out full of unmistakable good will and good faith, to provide a text in social history, and comes up with snappy entertainment at best, and at worst, an insult to the victims of whatever plight it undertook to inspect.^ ^ In another place. Wood suggests that "movies offer structures of thought and feeling to an almost inconceivable quantity of people, and we live on their legacy in ways we lave hardly begun to realize.Finally, Wood considers the impact of American films : The sociology of American movies thus becomes a question of the contribution of American movies to ideology; . . . of the extent to which the structures of moral and mental life in America and elsewhere correspond to structures to be found in films.^ ® The rise of image studies as a technique of film criti- bism seems to be closely aligned to questions of film genre studies. Film genres provide bodies of films which can be 'linked by common traditions and conventions, or by similar themes, characterizations, visual icons and symbols, and typical narrative structures. Marjorie Rosen's image study on film women can also be read as a study of the women's jfilm genre. Genre studies has a long history as a source of •literary classifications. Beginning with the Logic of Cate­ gories during the Enlightenment, the concept of grouping and categorization has been a valid tool in literary criticism. 13 In the field of film analysis, the application of image studies to the field of genre criticism will expand that field. In his useful volume. Theories of Film, Andrew Tudor discusses the difficulties involved in applying literary genre study devices to film criticism. He writes. This is not to suggest that genre terms are totally useless. It is merely that to employ them requires a much more methodical understanding of the workings of film. And this in turn requires that we specify a set of sociological and psychological context assumptions and construct explicit genre models within them. . . . [T]he genre concept is indispensable in more strictly social and psychological terms as a way of formulating the interplay between culture, audience, films, and film-makers. . . . In sum, then, genre terms seem best immediately employed in the analysis of the relation between groups of films, the cultures in which they are made and the cultures in which they are exhibited.^ ^ The current decade has seen a growing interest in spe­ cific film images and the development of those images during the course of film history. The values of these studies support further inquiry and investigation of other signifi­ cant filmic representations of individuals or groups. It is the argument of this study that one filmic group needs to be studied in particular: the Sioux Indians. Statement of the Problem The general problem to be studied is "What are the images presented in American films dealing with the Sioux 'Indians and how do those images compare to images of that same tribe as presented in historical, ethnographic, and autobiographical accounts?" The cinematic and historical Lmages will be compared in an attempt to demonstrate the yays in which film images are constructed, how and under 14 what circumstances they change, and how the presence or absence of a particular image affects the impact of the total film. The study will be carried out with respect to several distinct "images" which reoccur visually within a fairly large and representative group of films. The term "image" will refer to the visual appearance of costumes, lodging, locale, or life styles. It will also refer to the depiction of typically recurring events, such as conferences, battles, or hunting raids. The term "image" will also refer to recur­ ring aspects of character development, plot motivation, or narrative structure which reappear frequently in films. Specifically, this study will look at historical events or processes: Sioux Material Culture (such as housing, village jlife, dress, and body decoration); Sioux Social Organization (such as tribal councils, courting, and social roles); and images of Sioux religion and ceremonies (such as visions and the Sun Dance ceremony). Significance of the Problem The Sioux Indians deserve study as a film image group for a variety of reasons. In the first place. Plains Indi­ ans and the Sioux tribe in particular, represent an import­ ant part of film history. At least as early as 1894, when jthe silent film "Sioux Ghost Dance"^ ^ was made, American cowboys have been beating American Indians, all to the thrill and excitement of American audiences. The western _______________________________ : _1.5J ihas~hâd as lon<^ând as contirTuous a "r^igrT'of popularity as any film genre. The Sioux Indians were particularly impor­ tant because of their appearance, techniques of war, and their historic interactions with westward-bound Americans after the Civil War. It was the various tribes of the Plains who were characterized by war ponies, buffalo hunts, [bows-and-arrows, feathered war bonnets, secret bird calls, tent-like "Teepees," and lives of migration following the herds. Though there may have been close to a hundred dis­ tinct Native American tribes in the early nineteenth century, the twenty or so tribes which comprised the Plains Indians have retained the most stereotyped of images. The Sioux deserve individual study for an additional reason. Ralph and Natasha Friar have written one of the few volumes on the history of Indians as film images. Their book, The Only Good Indian: The Hollywood Gospel,-^® includes detailed indices to images of Indians in American films. According to the statistics, Sioux Indians have appeared in over eighty silent and sound films between the years 18 94 and 1971.^ ^ The Sioux have been represented, have been portrayed consistently during the long history of the west­ ern film genre, and have been filmed by almost every major motion picture production company. Listing sound-period films only, Sioux Indians have appeared in films produced by Universal, Fox, Buena-Vista, Warner Brothers, RKO, Columbia, Allied Artists, United Artists, Republic, and Paramount.^ ® The Sioux also merit analysis because of the political 16 and military confrontations which gave rise to such heroic figures as Chief Sitting Bull, General Benjamin Miles, Chief Crazy Horse, William F. Cody, General George Armstrong Custer, Chief Red Cloud, and others. The Sioux Massacre at the Battle of the Little Dig Horn has been filmed at least twenty-two times^® and represents one of the most important western film sub-genres. Specific analysis of the Sioux Indian image is impor­ tant for yet another reason. Ralph and Natasha Friar begin their book with a derisive discussion of the "melting pot theory" as it has related to Indians: Thanks to.the moving pictures, we can, let us say, lump the Apache tribes with the Mohawk Nation, call them "Indians" and assume not only a racial but an ethnic relationship as well. We do not, however, arbitrarily lump the people from Hungary with the people from the British Isles to define Caucasians, nor do we assume that the two peoples have any ethnic relationship.® ® The Friar's continue with a brief history of American coloni­ zation: Spanish, French, English, Dutch,Portuguese, Swedish, and Russian voyagers comprised the invading European minority. . . . To insure that we may gullibly accept the historic fallacy that our predeces­ sors came here to create a "free" nation, history books, in conjunction with the makers of filmic history, have conveniently omitted telling us about the many indigenous tribes or nations exterminated on behalf of freedom. Hollywood has continued to perpetuate the myth by creating either (1) a noble red man, or (2) a vicious savage, both of whom deny the white man his proper Christian right to this continent. No other race or culture depicted on film has been made to assume such a permanent fictional identity. . . . The fact is that the "American Indian" is the only legitimate native of this land. Yet he is racially, not ethnically, isolated in our minds as one minority. . . . Hollywood has continued to be a co-conspirator in committing cultural genocide by subverting the Native American's various ethnic identities and retaining him as a racial scape­ goat. ® ^ 17 Because the Sioux have cultural significance, because they were historically important in the westward expansion of European culture, because they are represented both historically and by studio within film history, and because they have not yet been studied in any significant way, the Sioux are worthy of filmic image analysis. The availability of contemporary historical and ethnographic documents per­ taining to the Sioux within Southern California archives provides feasibility to this proposed study. Most impor­ tantly, the concentrated emphasis on images pertaining to the Sioux people alone might help point out the multiplicity of ethnic images to which the Friars referred. In addition to elucidating the specific images of Sioux Indians in Ameri­ can films, the study will also help broaden and expand the significance and validity of image studies and content analyses in American film scholarship. References have been made to studies concerning the images of women. Blacks, homosexuals, and other groups. It is important to note that none of the identified studies other than these have attempted to compare film images in a historical or anthro­ pological way. Though the typical study certainly includes L historical point of view, that view usually refers to the years in which films were made, rather than to original [events themselves. By focusing film scholarship on a way of life which is limited by time and terrain, and by comparing a specific life style to the available filmed versions, we _______________________________________________________l-8j |carT begin” tb~~document the specific ways”~ih~which' ihbvi jreflect social history. The important question will not be whether or not the film images of Sioux Indians are accurate Rather, the concern will be to look at the ways in which film and history interact, the ways in which images change jover time, and the effects, if any, that "correct" images have on the impact of a film. Therefore, this study will add to present knowledge of films and to the scope of film image studies in the follow­ ing ways: 1. This study will apply image study techniques to a largely ignored populace : the component families of the Sioux Nation. 2. This study will apply the techniques of historical and anthropological research to the field of image study, which has generally focused on contemporary images and contemporary times. 3. This study will raise the issues of the interaction of historical, sociological, and cultural forces in the creation of public attitudes and values through film. Method of the Study The nature of the Problem calls for combining the techniques of historical research and film criticism. The •historical procedures of archival work will help to locate primary references on relevant topics, to internally and 19 [externally validate that historical material, and to estab­ lish a precise and documented portrait of Sioux Indian life, primarily of the last half of the nineteenth century. The I ■result of historical research will include the discovery of photographic, etched, and drawn pictures of Indian life and je vents. Autobiographical data will include diaries, cor­ respondence, and journals, and reference will also be made to government reports and military memorabilia. It is important to note, of course, that the age of a document is not also proof of its veracity. The victor of a battle may ■remember the events differently from a witness on the other side. A Quaker missionary may know more about the Sioux •language than about Sioux battle tactics. The potential Diases of all historical sources must be carefully consid- jsred. The historical research is not necessarily limited to primary sources. Used with care, contemporary newspaper, magazine, and broadside accounts can be of great value, as jean published biographies, autobiographies, anthropologists' reports, and published trial or government transcripts. The nature of the problem also calls for the techniques bf critical film analysis. This tool of film research includes detailed content analysis of selected films and jutilizes screenplays, film stills, viewed films, and both jDral (taped) and written descriptions of those films. Critical research also includes recourse to film reviews and publications, to appropriate genre studies, and to other 20 relevant'materials"^ Content analysis depends upon repeated viewings of significant films— usually in sixteen millimeter format— and very close analysis of particular sequences. A film viewer or projector with "freeze-frame" capability was used in most cases. The historical and critical phases of research included primary and secondary sources. The first phase of research involved the identification and review of materials dealing with the Sioux. The second phase of research involved the 'identification and location of films dealing with the Sioux in important ways. The final phase of research involved the Letailed analysis of the identified films and the appropri­ ate comparisons to the other materials. Overview of Sioux History The history of Sioux-American relations began on shaky grounds. In 1805, Zebulon Pike negotiated a treaty with a Sioux tribe whereby some nine square miles of land at the mouth of the St. Croix River was given up for the construc­ tion of an American fort. The Sioux were to receive $2000. The fort was constructed, the treaty was ratified, but the President never confirmed the treaty, and the money was never paid. Ten years later, a second treaty was negotiated. This 'document, entitled "A Treaty of Peace and Friendship," was Doth ratified and confirmed, for its terms were of great importance. During most of the eighteenth century, the only jEuropean presence on the American Plains was that of the French. French trappers, traders, explorers, and missionar- Les had successfully negotiated friendships with a variety of Indian tribes. During the subsequent French-American pars, those tribes had aligned themselves with the French. Even though those alliances were far removed from the actual oattlefields and though the Indians did little to further the French cause, still the victorious Americans began a process of meticulous negotiations with each tribe. In three separate treaties, various Sioux units pledged "per­ petual peace and friendship between the United States and 34 individuals of the Teeton Tribe," and the chiefs acknowl­ edged "themselves and their afore said tribe to be under the protection of the U.S.A. and no other nation."^ By 1824, diplomatic relations were becoming more com­ plex. There was building pressure on the one hand to elimi­ nate all Indian presence from the Eastern seaboard. There was also pressure brought by traders and mercantile inter­ ests to keep the westward-moving frontier safe for commerce. In 1825, separate treaties were negotiated with the Teton, Yancton, Yanktonai, Ogallala, Hunkpapa, and other Sioux tribes. These treaties sanctified the activities of American-authorized traders and dealers. Non-authorized traders were to be banned from Indian lands, but the Sioux were required to allow free travel to anyone with American authorization. The Sioux also promised never to sell or exchange firearms or other weapons, and promised not to ■retaliate against individual Whites who violated the treaty provision. The Treaty talked about limiting Whites to "mild and equitable regulations" but provided neither penalties nor methods for enforcing the informal provisions. These provisions may have had significance in light of later Development, but at the time of negotiation, they were not controversial.
